body_html:
I'm not 100% sure what the problem is here, but I think this is working as intended:

  • features is a 5 x 10 matrix (2-D tensor).
  • tf.shape(features) is a length-2 vector (1-D tensor), which will evaluate to [5, 10].
  • tf.shape(features)[0] is a scalar (0-D tensor), which will evaluate to 5.
  • tf.shape(features)[0].shape is the tf.TensorShape representing the (static) shape of tf.shape(features)[0]. It evaluates to TensorShape([]), which represents a scalar (0-D tensor => empty list of dimensions).
body_text:
I'm not 100% sure what the problem is here, but I think this is working as intended:

features is a 5 x 10 matrix (2-D tensor).
tf.shape(features) is a length-2 vector (1-D tensor), which will evaluate to [5, 10].
tf.shape(features)[0] is a scalar (0-D tensor), which will evaluate to 5.
tf.shape(features)[0].shape is the tf.TensorShape representing the (static) shape of tf.shape(features)[0]. It evaluates to TensorShape([]), which represents a scalar (0-D tensor => empty list of dimensions).
body:
I'm not 100% sure what the problem is here, but I think this is working as intended:

* `features` is a 5 x 10 matrix (2-D tensor).
* `tf.shape(features)` is a length-2 vector (1-D tensor), which will evaluate to `[5, 10]`.
* `tf.shape(features)[0]` is a scalar (0-D tensor), which will evaluate to `5`.
* `tf.shape(features)[0].shape` is the `tf.TensorShape` representing the (static) shape of `tf.shape(features)[0]`. It evaluates to `TensorShape([])`, which represents a scalar (0-D tensor => empty list of dimensions).
